revisions.rev:
{{Infobox NFL_season | logo = | team = Tennessee Titans | year = 2009 | record = 8â8 | division_place = 3rd [[AFC South]] | coach = [[Jeff Fisher]] | stadium = [[LP Field]] | playoffs = ''did not qualify'' | pro bowlers = | AP All-pros = [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] ''(1st team)''
[[Michael Roos]] ''(2nd team)'' | uniform = }} The '''[[2009 NFL season|2009]] [[Tennessee Titans]] season''' is the 50th season for the original [[American Football League]] team, their 40th in the NFL, and 13th in Tennessee. The Titans aimed to equal or improve on their 2008 NFL best 13â3 record; however, they lost the first 6 games of that season. The Titans won 7 out of their next 8 games before a 42â17 loss to the Chargers in Week 16 eliminated the team from playoff contention. Second-year running back [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] won the [[List of NFL rushing champions|NFL rushing title]] with 2,006 rushing yards, and set the NFL record for most [[yards from scrimmage]] in a single season, with 2,509. ==Schedule== The Titans played the [[Buffalo Bills]] on August 8 in the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame Game]], pitting teams owned by [[Bud Adams]] (Titans) and [[Ralph C. Wilson, Jr.]] (Bills). They are the only surviving members of the ''"[[Foolish Club]]"'', the eight original owners of American Football League franchises. The 2009 Professional Football season will celebrate what would have been the AFL's 50th. Both the Bills and Titans wore AFL throwbacks, with the Titans in [[Houston Oilers]] uniforms. ===Preseason=== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; font-size:95%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week ! rowspan="2" | Date ! rowspan="2" | Kickoff ([[Central Time Zone|CDT]]) ! rowspan="2" | Opponent ! colspan="2" | Results ! rowspan="2" | Game Site ! rowspan="2" | TV ! rowspan="2" | NFL Recap |- ! Division games are in '''bold''' text.

{{note|localtv|a}}Originally scheduled as a 3:15pm (CDT) kickoff. |} ==Standings== {{2009 AFC South standings}} ==Regular season results== ===Week 1: at Pittsburgh Steelers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Titans |R1=0||R2=7||R3=0||R4=3||R5=0||RT=10 |Home='''Steelers''' |H1=0||H2=7||H3=0||H4=3||H5=3||HT=13 |stadium= [[Heinz Field]], [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] |time= 8:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] / 7:30 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CDT]] |weather= 67Â°F (Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 65,110 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NBC]]|TVAnnouncers=[[Al Michaels]], [[Cris Collinsworth]], & [[Andrea Kremer]] }} The Titans began their season at [[Heinz Field]] for the annual [[National Football League Kickoff game|kickoff game]] against the defending Super Bowl champions, the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. After a scoreless first quarter, Tennessee trailed near the end of the second quarter as Steelers quarterback [[Ben Roethlisberger]] completed a 34-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Santonio Holmes]]. Afterwards, the Titans would tie the game as quarterback [[Kerry Collins]] completed a 16-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Justin Gage]]. After a scoreless third quarter, Tennessee took the lead as kicker [[Rob Bironas]] got a 45-yard field goal, while Pittsburgh kicker [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] made a 32-yard field goal to tie the game. In overtime, the Steelers got the win as Reed nailed a game-winning 33-yard field goal. With the loss, the Titans started the season out at 0â1. ===Week 2: vs. Houston Texans=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Texans''' |R1=7||R2=17||R3=7||R4=3||RT=34 |Home=Titans |H1=14||H2=10||H3=7||H4=0||HT=31 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] / 12:00 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CDT]] |weather= 71Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 69,143 |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]]|TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] & [[Steve Tasker]] }} Hoping to rebound from their loss against the Steelers, the Titans went home for their Week 2 home opener against their AFC South foe, the [[Houston Texans]]. Tennessee would strike first in the opening quarter as running back [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] got a 57-yard touchdown run. The Texans would answer with quarterback [[Matt Schaub]] completing a 19-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Andre Johnson]], yet the Titans would reply with quarterback [[Kerry Collins]] completing a 69-yard touchdown pass to Johnson. Tennessee would add onto their lead in the second quarter as Collins completed a 8-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Nate Washington]]. However, Houston took the lead as Schaub completed a 72-yard touchdown pass to Johnson and a 29-yard touchdown pass to [[Jacoby Jones]], followed by a 38-yard field goal from kicker [[Kris Brown]]. The Titans would close out the half as kicker [[Rob Bironas]] made a 40-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Tennessee would regain the lead as Johnson got a 91-yard touchdown run. The Texans would tie the game again as Schaub completed a 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Owen Daniels]]. In the fourth quarter, Houston took the lead as Brown nailed a 23-yard field goal. Afterwards, the Texans' defense prevented any attempt at an offensive rally. With the loss, the Titans drop to 0â2. ===Week 3: at New York Jets=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Titans |R1=0||R2=10||R3=7||R4=0||RT=17 |Home='''Jets''' |H1=14||H2=0||H3=7||H4=3||HT=24 |stadium= [[Giants Stadium|The Meadowlands]], [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] / 12:00 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CDT]] |weather= 66Â°F (Rainy) |attendance= 75,863 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] & [[Dan Dierdorf]] }} Trying to snap a two-game losing skid, the Titans flew to [[Giants Stadium|The Meadowlands]], donned their Houston Oilers throwbacks, and played a Week 3 AFL Legacy game with the [[New York Jets]]. Tennessee would struggle in the first quarter as Jets quarterback [[Mark Sanchez]] got a 14-yard touchdown run and completed a 2-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Ben Hartsock]]. The Titans would climb into the game in the second quarter with running back [[LenDale White]]'s 5-yard touchdown run and kicker [[Rob Bironas]]' 38-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Tennessee would take the lead with quarterback [[Kerry Collins]]' 9-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Nate Washington]]. However, New York would strike back with Sanchez's 6-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Jerricho Cotchery]]. The Jets would increase their lead in the fourth quarter with kicker [[Jay Feely]]'s 48-yard field goal. The Titans tried to rally, but New York's defense would stand firm and prevented any possible comeback attempt. With the loss, Tennessee would fall to 0â3 for the first time since the 2006 season. ===Week 4: at Jacksonville Jaguars=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Titans |R1=0||R2=3||R3=6||R4=8||RT=17 |Home='''Jaguars''' |H1=10||H2=17||H3=3||H4=7||HT=37 |stadium= [[Jacksonville Municipal Stadium]], [[Jacksonville, Florida]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] / 12:00 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CDT]] |weather= 79Â°F (Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 49,014 |referee= [[Alberto Riveron]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} Hoping to save their season, the Titans flew to [[Jacksonville Municipal Stadium]] for a Week 4 AFC South duel with the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]. Tennessee would trail early in the first quarter as Jaguars kicker [[Josh Scobee]] got a 22-yard field goal, followed by running back [[Maurice Jones-Drew (running back)|Maurice Jones-Drew]]'s 9-yard Touchdown. The Titans would get in the game in the second quarter with kicker [[Rob Bironas]] making a 29-yard field goal. However, Jacksonville came right back with quarterback [[David Garrard]] completing a 9-yard and a 15-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Mike Sims-Walker]], with Scobee's 50-yard field goal in between. The Jaguars would continue to build their lead as Scobee nailed a 33-yard field goal. Tennessee would then begin its comeback attempt with quarterback [[Kerry Collins]] completing a 14-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Nate Washington]] (with a failed 2-point conversion). The Titans kept their rally going in the fourth quarter with Collins getting a 10-yard touchdown run, followed by running back [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]]'s 2-point conversion run. However, Jacksonville would pull away with Garrard's 33-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Marcedes Lewis]]. With this loss, Tennessee fell to 0â4. ===Week 5: vs. Indianapolis Colts=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Colts''' |R1=7||R2=14||R3=7||R4=3||RT=31 |Home=Titans |H1=6||H2=3||H3=0||H4=0||HT=9 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 8:20 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] / 7:20 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CDT]] |weather= 57Â°F (Clear) |attendance= 69,143 |referee= [[Walt Anderson (American football)|Walt Anderson]] |TV=[[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Al Michaels]], [[Cris Collinsworth]], & [[Andrea Kremer]] }} Down four games, the Titans went home for a Week 5 Sunday night duel with their AFC South rival, the [[Indianapolis Colts]]. Tennessee would trail in the first quarter as Colts quarterback [[Peyton Manning]] found wide receiver [[Reggie Wayne]] on a 3-yard touchdown pass. The Titans would answer with a 49-yard and a 43-yard field goal from kicker [[Rob Bironas]], but Indianapolis came right back in the second quarter with running back [[Joseph Addai]]'s 1-yard touchdown run. Tennessee tried to keep it close with Bironas nailing a 46-yard field goal, yet the Colts continued its domination with Manning hooking up with wide receiver [[Austin Collie]] on a 39-yard touchdown pass. Afterwards, Indianapolis would pull away in the second half. Manning connected with Collie again on a 6-yard touchdown pass, followed by kicker [[Adam Vinatieri]] booting a 23-yard field goal. With the loss, the Titans fell to 0â5. ===Week 6: at New England Patriots=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Titans |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=0||RT=0 |Home='''Patriots''' |H1=10||H2=35||H3=14||H4=0||HT=59 |stadium= [[Gillette Stadium]], [[Foxborough, Massachusetts]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] / 3:15 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CDT]] |weather= 33Â°F (Rain/Snow) |attendance= 68,756 |referee= [[Gene Steratore]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Jim Nantz]] & [[Phil Simms]] }} Still looking for their first win of the season, the Titans flew to [[Gillette Stadium]], donned Oilers throwback uniforms, and played a Week 6 AFL Legacy game with the [[New England Patriots]] in a rare October snowstorm. Tennessee's struggles continued as Patriots running back [[Laurence Maroney]] got a 45-yard touchdown run, followed by kicker [[Stephen Gostkowski]] making a 33-yard field goal. Things got worse for the Titans in the second quarter as quarterback [[Tom Brady]] completed five touchdown passes, two to wide receiver [[Randy Moss]] (40-yard and 28-yard), one to running back [[Kevin Faulk]] (38-yard), and two to wide receiver [[Wes Welker]] (30-yard and 5-yard). New England would then conclude their scoring in the third quarter with Brady's 9-yard touchdown pass to Moss, followed by backup quarterback [[Brian Hoyer]]'s one-yard touchdown run. With the loss, not only did the Titans go into the bye week at 0â6 (their first such start since 1984), but they suffered their worst loss in franchise history, eclipsing a 61â7 loss to Cincinnati in 1989, when the team was the Houston Oilers. This was the first 59â0 game since 1976, and only the fourth in NFL history. it was the biggest blowout in the 2009 NFL season. ===Week 7: BYE=== ===Week 8: vs. Jacksonville Jaguars=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Jaguars |R1=0||R2=7||R3=6||R4=0||RT=13 |Home='''Titans''' |H1=3||H2=10||H3=10||H4=7||HT=30 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 3:05 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 59Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 69,143 |referee= [[Pete Morelli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] & [[Steve Tasker]] }} Coming off their bye week, the Titans went home for a Week 8 AFC South rematch with the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]. In this game, quarterback [[Vince Young]] would make his first start since Week 1 of the 2008 NFL season. Tennessee got off to a fast start in the first quarter with kicker [[Rob Bironas]] booting a 48-yard field goal. In the second quarter, the Titans would add onto their lead as Young hooked up with wide receiver [[Nate Washington]] on a 6-yrd touchdown pass, followed by Bironas nailing a 25-yard field goal. The Jaguars would answer with an 80-yard touchdown run from running back [[Maurice Jones-Drew]]. In the third quarter, Jacksonville would tie the game as Jones-Drew got a 79-yard touchdown run (with a blocked PAT), yet Tennessee came right back with a 52-yard touchdown run from running back [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] and a 45-yard field goal from Bironas. Afterwards, the Titans pulled away in the fourth quarter with Johnson getting an 89-yard touchdown. With the win, Tennessee improved to 1â6. This would become the first game in NFL history where there were 4 touchdown runs of 50 or more yards. Also, Johnson (24 carries for 228 yards) and Jones-Drew (8 carries for 177 yards) would join the Browns' [[Bobby Mitchell]] (14 carries for 232 yards) and the Redskins' [[Johnny Olszewski]] (18 carries for 190 yards) on November 15, 1959 as the only pair of opposing running backs to both have at least 175 yards rushing in the same game. ===Week 9: at San Francisco 49ers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Titans''' |R1=3||R2=7||R3=7||R4=17||RT=34 |Home=49ers |H1=3||H2=14||H3=0||H4=10||HT=27 |stadium= [[Candlestick Park]], [[San Francisco, California]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 3:15 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 63Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 69,732 |referee= [[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Coming off their divisional home win over the Jaguars, the Titans flew to [[Candlestick Park]] for a Week 9 interconference duel with the [[San Francisco 49ers]]. Tennessee would trail early in the first quarter as 49ers kicker [[Joe Nedney]] got a 40-yard field goal, yet the Titans would answer with kicker [[Rob Bironas]] making a 21-yard field goal. The Titans would take the lead in the second quarter as quarterback [[Vince Young]] got a 10-yard touchdown run, but San Francisco would close out the half with a 3-yard touchdown run from running back [[Frank Gore]] and a 12-yard touchdown pass from quarterback [[Alex Smith]] to wide receiver [[Jason Hill (American football)|Jason Hill]]. In the third quarter, Tennessee would tie the game as running back [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] got a 1-yard touchdown. The 49ers would retake their lead in the fourth quarter with Nedney nailing a 25-yard field goal, yet the Titans would regain the lead with Johnson's 2-yard touchdown run, Bironas' 28-yard field goal, and cornerback [[Cortland Finnegan]]'s 39-yard interception return for a touchdown. San Francisco tried to make a comeback as Smith found Hill again on a 3-yard touchdown pass, yet Tennessee's defense held up for the victory. With the win, the Titans improved to 2â6. ===Week 10: vs. Buffalo Bills=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Bills |R1=7||R2=7||R3=3||R4=0||RT=17 |Home='''Titans''' |H1=14||H2=3||H3=0||H4=24||HT=41 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 12:00 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 68Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 69,143 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Coming off their road win over the 49ers, the Titans went home, donned their Houston Oilers throwbacks, and played a Week 10 AFL Legacy game with the [[Buffalo Bills]]. Tennessee would trail early in the first quarter as Bills running back [[Fred Jackson (American football)|Fred Jackson]] threw a 27-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Lee Evans (American football)|Lee Evans]]. The Titans would respond as running back [[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] got a 28-yard touchdown run, followed by quarterback [[Vince Young]] hooking up with wide receiver [[Nate Washington]] on a 14-yard touchdown pass. In the second quarter, Tennessee would increase their lead as kicker [[Rob Bironas]] booted a 38-yard field goal. Buffalo would end the half with quarterback [[Trent Edwards]] finding Evans on an 8-yard touchdown pass. The Bills would tie the game in the third quarter with kicker [[Rian Lindell]] booting a 25-yard field goal, yet the Titans would explode with points in the fourth quarter. It began with Johnson's 1-yard touchdown run, followed by Bironas' 51-yard field goal. It would follow up with safety [[Vincent Fuller (American football)|Vincent Fuller]] returning an interception 26 yards for a touchdown and cornerback [[Rod Hood]] returning an inteception 31 yards for a touchdown. With the win, Tennessee would improve to 3â6. Chris Johnson (26 carries, 132 yards, 2 TDs and 9 catches, 100 yards) would join [[Billy Cannon]] as the only players in franchise history to rush and receive for 100 yards in one game. He would also join [[Earl Campbell]] in 1980 as the only players in franchise history to have two rushing touchdowns in three-straight games. ===Week 11: at Houston Texans=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Titans''' |R1=0||R2=14||R3=3||R4=3||RT=20 |Home=Texans |H1=7||H2=7||H3=3||H4=0||HT=17 |stadium= [[Reliant Stadium]], [[Houston, Texas]] |time= 8:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 7:30 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 66Â°F (Clear) |attendance= 71,153 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Jon Gruden]] & [[Michelle Tafoya]] }} Coming off their win over the Bills, the Titans flew to Reliant Stadium for an AFC South rivalry match against the [[Houston Texans]]. In the first quarter the Titans trailed early as QB [[Matt Schaub]] got a 3-yard touchdown pass to RB [[Steve Slaton]]. In the second quarter they replied with QB [[Vince Young]] completing a 13-yard touchdown pass to WR [[Kenny Britt]]. Then Houston tried to pull away as Schaub hooked up with WR [[Andre Johnson]] on a 13-yard touchdown pass, until the Titans replied again with RB [[LenDale White]] making a 1-yard touchdown run. The Titans got the lead in the third quarter as kicker [[Rob Bironas]] made a 50-yard field goal, but the Texans replied to tie the game when kicker [[Kris Brown]] made a 26-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter the Titans scored for the win when Bironas got a 53-yard field goal. Brown had a chance to tie the game and sent it into overtime for the second game in a row and for the second game in a row he missed giving the Titans the victory. With the win, the Titans improve to 4â6. ===Week 12: vs. Arizona Cardinals=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Cardinals |R1=0||R2=3||R3=7||R4=7||RT=17 |Home='''Titans''' |H1=3||H2=3||H3=7||H4=7||HT=20 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 3:15 PM [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 59Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 69,143 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Sam Rosen (sportscaster)|Sam Rosen]], [[Tim Ryan (American football)|Tim Ryan]] & [[Charissa Thompson]] }} The game would start with a Rob Bironas field goal to take a 3 nothing lead. However, to end the first half, Tennessee was holding the defending NFC champs 6â3, but an extended play with 5 seconds left on Arizona's 20 or so, would diminish Tennessees chances for a field goal. Tennessee scored the first touchdown during the second half to take a 13â3 lead, but Arizona scored 14 straight points with the help of Lerod Stevens-Howling returning a kickoff for a touchdown. Facing a 17â13 deficit at their own 1 yard line, Vince Young led the Titans on an 18 play drive which featured him throwing for 94 yards, running for 5 and converting three 4th downs including a 4th & goal to [[Kenny Britt]] as time expired for a touchdown to win 20â17. The win improved the team to 5â6 and marked the first time in NFL history that a team won five-straight games after losing their first six. ===Week 13: at Indianapolis Colts=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Titans |R1=3||R2=7||R3=0||R4=7||RT= |Home='''Colts''' |H1=7||H2=17||H3=0||H4=3||HT= |stadium= [[Lucas Oil Stadium]], [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 12:00 PM [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= None (Retractable Roof Closed) |attendance= 66,321 |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Tennessee Titans}}; color:white; |scoring= ;1st Quarter *IND  â [[Joseph Addai]] 8 yard run, 13:02 ([[Matt Stover]] kick), ''Colts 7â0.'' '''''Drive: 5 plays, 75 yards, 1:58.''''' *TEN  â [[Rob Bironas]] 20 yard field goal, 6:34. ''Colts 7â3.'' '''''Drive: 13 plays, 69 yards, 6:28.''''' ;2nd Quarter *IND  â Joseph Addai 1 yard run, 11:42 (Stover kick), ''Colts 14â3.'' '''''Drive: 10 plays, 77 yards, 3:56.''''' *IND  â [[Austin Collie]] 4 yard pass from [[Peyton Manning]], 1:55 (Stover kick), ''Colts 21â3.'' '''''Drive: 9 plays, 42 yards, 3:48.''''' *TEN  â [[Kenny Britt]] 6 yard pass from [[Vince Young]], 0:20 (Bironas kick), ''Colts 21â10.'' '''''Drive: 8 plays, 66 yards, 1:35.''''' *IND  â Matt Stover 43 yard field goal, 0:00, ''Colts 24â10.'' '''''Drive: 6 plays, 46 yards, 1:51.''''' }} ===Week 14: vs. St. Louis Rams=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Rams |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=7||RT=7 |Home='''Titans''' |H1=14||H2=9||H3=10||H4=14||HT=47 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 3:05 PM [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 54Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 69,143 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Chris Rose]] & [[Trent Green]] }} ===Week 15: vs. Miami Dolphins=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=3||R2=3||R3=3||R4=15||R5=0 |Home='''Titans''' |H1=7||H2=10||H3=7||H4=0||H5=3 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 12:00 PM [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= |attendance= |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} With both teams fighting for their playoff lives the Titans clawed to a 24â9 lead over the Dolphins, but two fourth quarter touchdowns by [[Chad Henne]] forced overtime. Henne, however, was intercepted in overtime, setting up a 46-yard game-winning [[Rob Bironas]] field goal. ===Week 16: vs. San Diego Chargers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Chargers''' |R1=7||R2=14||R3=14||R4=7||RT=42 |Home=Titans |H1=3||H2=7||H3=0||H4=7||HT=17 |stadium= [[LP Field]], [[Nashville, Tennessee]] |time= 7:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 6:30 PM [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= |attendance= |referee= [[Tony Corrente]] |TV=[[NFL Network|NFLN]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Bob Papa]] & [[Matt Millen]] }} ===Week 17: at Seattle Seahawks=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Titans''' |R1=7||R2=0||R3=3||R4=7||RT= |Home=Seahawks |H1=0||H2=7||H3=3||H4=3||HT= |stadium= [[Qwest Field]], [[Seattle, Washington]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] / 3:15 PM [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= |attendance= |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} ==Final roster== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="7" style="{{NFLPrimaryColor|Tennessee Titans}};
